results.title: Jaara Nyilamum
results.creator_credit: Lou Bennett AM and Romaine Moreton
results.credit_line:
Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung) and Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Warrung, Yorta Yorta)
Single-channel video, 7:39 mins.
Filmed and edited by Romaine Moreton
Co-directed by Romaine Moreton and Lou Bennett AM
ACMI Collection

Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet
Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM
Arranged by Iain Grandage
Produced by Stephen Snelleman
results.brief_description:
2021, Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung), Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Warrung, Yorta Yorta)
Filmed & Edited by Romaine Moreton, Co-Directed by Romaine Moreton & Lou Bennett AM
H264 projection,16:9, colour, 7:39 mins
Jaara Nyilamum (song composition) Performed by Dr Lou Bennett AM and the Australian String Quartet, Composed by Dr Lou Bennett AM, Arranged by Iain Grandage, Produced by Stephen Snelleman

Dr Lou Bennett is a Performer, Songwriter, Musical and Artistic Director, Composer, Actor, Soundscape Designer and Academic. Lou’s research project ‘Sovereign Language Rematriation Through Song Pedagogy’ focusses on the importance and relevance of Indigenous language retrieval, reclamation, and regeneration through the medium of the Arts to enhance community health and wellbeing. Dr Romaine Moreton is an artist, writer, performer, filmmaker, and her proposes an Indigenous philosophy of story-telling and embodied knowledge, with her work constantly drawing our attention back to the importance of the breath in Indigenous cultural practices.

The making of Jaara Nyilamum (2021) evoked a stillness that restored us to full sensual immersion within country, and from this place of rooted calmness, country reaffirmed our Law is real. Jaara Nyilamum became most profound when we realised this was more than a film about ceremony, but was in fact, ceremony itself. Our challenge was to create a production model that aligned with our beliefs and centralised our Law, pushed back against monochronic time and engaged with the deep cycles of place, where we embraced Belonging as a process of constant renewal and Rematration.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Romaine Moreton (Goenpul Yagerabul Minjungbal Bundjalung), Dr Lou Bennett AM (Dja Dja Warrung, Yorta Yorta)

results.title: A Horse with stripes
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Andrew Ross and Andrew O'Sullivan
results.brief_description: Manicured lawns…immaculate houses…clean streets…but beneath this highly desirable exterior lurks the desperation of the bored, the scared, the paranoid and the violent. And when the tranquil suburban life of the Goldings and the Bates deteriorates into chaos, they choose not to speak about it. Winner of Silver Hugo, Best short drama, Chicago International Film Festival, USA, 1991.

results.title: Roses are red
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Robert Connolly and Marcella Hayward
results.brief_description: Joy and Di are two women on a mission, but Di wonders whether Joy has got what it takes. Joy wonders if she has got what it takes. After all, it’s not easy being a parking cop. Brian thinks it’s even tougher being a flower seller - and the last thing he needs is a parking ticket. Starring David Wenham (‘Lord of the Rings’), Kris McQuade and Jacqueline McKenzie. Original format 35mm.

results.title: Dressing Dad
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Isabel Perez and Sofya Gollan
results.brief_description: A short student film in which the filmmaker explores how the relationship with her father was transformed by the knowledge of his being a cross-dresser. Featuring interviews with her father and his transvestite friends, this work dispels many of the common preconceptions about cross-dressing and transvestitism while also being an engaging study of how families cope with aspects of individual difference and gender exploration.

results.title: Universal Appliance Co.
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Michaeley O'Brien, Ruth Kleinhenz and Andrew Lancaster
results.brief_description: 1. An inventor finally gets a chance to mass produce his latest creation at the Universal Appliance Company factory. The production line runs smoothly until advertising and romance become distractions. Another multi-award winning production for director and sound designer Andrew Lancaster.

results.title: Grace
results.brief_description: Returning from her adopted home in London, to attend the funeral of her sister, an Aboriginal woman finds herself isolated from both kin and culture. This emotionally mature and complex work moves beyond didactism and easily digestable polemics to suggest that cultural dislocation is written as much in the body, in language and the psyche as it is in economics and politics. By suggesting that the effects for the “stolen generation” were as destructive for inter-Aboriginal relationships as they were for black and white relations in this country, “Grace” is a devastating and confronting exploration of what it means to have been “stolen”.

results.title: Strike your heart (A)
results.creator_credit: Wayne Barker, Nicki Lukacs and Strike Your Heart Productions
results.brief_description: Strike Your Heart is a gentle portrait of change; its happiness and heartbreak for a boy, a family and a culture. It is 1967 and Australian Aborigines have won the battle for their citizenship rights. New attitudes are being embraced by all and for a ten-year-old boy (Rami Rahman) living in the quiet coastal town of Broome, North-Western Australia, there are personal challenges that have to be faced - falling in love, his first kiss, heartbreak and departure from his close-knit Aboriginal family. Filmed on location in Broome, Western Australia - Wayne Barker’s homelands, with an indigenous cast from the region, “Strike Your Heart” is the first indigenous drama made in Western Australia. Cast includes Jimmy Edgar, Petris Torres, Attika Edgar, Alison Torres, Sylvia Clarke, Stephen ‘Baamba’Albert, Emmanuelle Torres, Brian T. Eastwell.

results.title: Cass: no saucepan diver
results.creator_credit: Wayne Barker and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: In 1982 Aboriginal filmmaker Wayne Barker returned to his home in Broome, Western Australia to make a film about his grandfather, Cass Drummond. The result is this personal portrait of a staunchly self-reliant old man as he looks back on his life in the pearling industry and comments on what it was like to be an Aboriginal earlier this century.
